His happy, humorous vein, and rugged style,</br>His rough and careless thoughts, from fancy beam'd,</br>Mark Chaucer's song, the Druid of our Isle,</br>That led our bards, to distant region's fam'd!
Next Spencer wrote his rude inchanting lays;</br>The light thought hovers o'er his fairy scene;</br>The Virtues lent him his immortal praise,</br>He sung their beauties each with mind serene.
Shakespeare, the glass of Nature, where we view</br>The passions flashing on with vivid blaze!</br>Held all in doubt to deem his visions true,</br>And darted, quick as thought, thro' Reason's maze.
From Milton's page inferior scripture flow'd,</br>Some angel seem'd to breath each note divine!</br>The hallow'd fire flamed up to Nature's God,</br>While tears humane confess'd the mortal line!
With warm ideas beaming strong from thought,</br>Still on the waver and Aolian air,</br>Pope struck the lyre, or reason'd as he ought,</br>When moral truth obtain'd his pious care.

How, Thomson!  can a worthless bard rehearse</br>Thy goodness, thy warm tenderness of soul,</br>That flows and vibrates still thro' every verse,</br>That melts the touch'd heart ere we reach the goal!
Poor Collins sung, but Nature could not bear—</br>The wild bard fainted in his sister's arms,</br>He sigh'd and died — pale Fancy dropt a tear</br>To see her son o'erpowered by her charms.

While Nature slept around, Young's dreadless mind</br>Roam'd thro' the stilly dread of night alone,</br>Each scarce-heard echo of the whistling wind</br>Crept to his soul, and death was all his groan.
Wife, children lost, and friends just gone before,</br>Intrude the dreary thought on wretched man,</br>We laugh away with health the present hour,</br>The next with sorrow live on Wisdom's plan.</br>
